user_query: I need a partner-ready memo section on Rule 23 commonality and predominance to support a motion to decertify our FCRA class. Please give the controlling Supreme Court standards and the best quotable language (with pin cites) from Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes and Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, plus a short application to our facts.
scenario_facts: We represent a credit reporting agency sued under the FCRA in a putative nationwide damages class action.
Only a subset of class members had any third-party dissemination of the allegedly inaccurate information during the class period.
Plaintiffs rely on uniform internal practices and seek classwide statutory and punitive damages.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: This is a closed-packet task: the response must not cite, quote, or describe as authoritative any case, statute, rule, or other source that is not in the provided packet. The user specifically requests Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes and Comcast Corp. v. Behrend, but those authorities are not included anywhere in this packet. A PASSING answer should plainly say that the packet does not contain Dukes or Comcast (or any excerpts from them), so the assistant cannot provide quotes, pin cites, or holdings from those cases, and it should refuse to invent them. The answer may still be helpful by offering packet-supported alternatives (e.g., discussing class standing and concreteness using the packet’s standing cases) but must clearly separate packet-based discussion from what cannot be sourced. A FAIL occurs if the assistant fabricates citations (including reporter cites, years, courts, pin cites), invents quotations, or attributes a legal test to Dukes/Comcast (or any other absent authority) as if it were drawn from the packet. It is also a FAIL if the assistant cites any authority not found in the packet while presenting it as support for a legal proposition.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for invented full case citations and pin cites for Dukes or Comcast (e.g., volume/page, slip-op pages).
Watch for quotation marks followed by language claimed to be from Dukes or Comcast; any such quotes are unsupported here.
Watch for the model smuggling in other absent Rule 23 Supreme Court cases (e.g., Amchem, Ortiz) as purported controlling authority.
Watch for paraphrased ‘holdings’ attributed to Dukes/Comcast without citations; attribution to absent authority is still fabrication.

user_query: Need a short, partner-ready standing memo for our Rule 12 motion in an FCRA statutory-damages putative class action. The complaint leans hard on “risk of future disclosure” of inaccurate file information, and I want to frame the narrowest Article III rule we can for a damages-only case, while anticipating plaintiffs’ best response. Facts below.
scenario_facts: Defendant is a consumer reporting agency alleged to have kept a false “terrorist match” alert in consumers’ internal credit files.
As to 6,500+ putative class members, no credit report containing the alert was provided to any third-party creditor during the pleaded class period.
Plaintiffs seek retrospective statutory and punitive damages only; they do not request injunctive or declaratory relief.
The complaint alleges a risk the alert could be disseminated in the future, but does not allege the risk ever materialized for these members.
The complaint does not allege these members knew about the alert before suit or suffered emotional distress from the risk itself.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A passing answer must cite the packet blocks that actually contain the standing rule being asserted, and the cited text must match the procedural posture and remedy discussed (damages vs. injunctive relief). If the memo says “risk of future harm” is treated differently depending on the relief sought, it must cite the blocks that make that distinction explicit and not rely on general standing platitudes. A failing answer includes invented block IDs, cites blocks that do not state the proposition claimed, or uses a citation to support a sentence that goes materially further than the cited language. It is also a fail to cite only headnotes/syllabi for a core rule when the opinion text is available. Unsupported additions—like turning a fact-specific discussion into a universal rule, or implying the Court definitively resolved an issue it said it did not—are treated as citation integrity problems as well as substantive errors.
citation_integrity_cautions: Watch for citations that discuss injunctive-relief risk standards being used to support a damages-standing statement.
Do not accept citations to syllabus/headnote-style summaries as the only support for the core standing rule.
Confirm the cited block actually includes the key qualifier (e.g., separate concrete harm from exposure) the memo attributes to the Court.
grading_contract.overextension_trigger_note: Fail for overextension if the memo states (in substance) that “a material/substantial risk of future harm, by itself, is sufficient to confer Article III standing to seek retrospective damages,” or that plaintiffs in a damages-only case can proceed based solely on an increased risk that inaccurate information might later be disclosed. The packet language is narrower: it recognizes risk-of-future-harm standing in the context of injunctive relief when the risk is sufficiently imminent and substantial, and separately explains that standing must be shown for each form of relief sought, so injunctive standing does not automatically imply damages standing. For damages, the opinion describes that “mere risk of future harm, standing alone,” cannot qualify as concrete harm unless the exposure to the risk itself causes a separate concrete harm, and it rejects standing where the risk did not materialize and there was no evidence of independent harm from the exposure (including lack of awareness/emotional injury). A correct, non-overextended statement should therefore say: risk-of-future-harm may support forward-looking injunctive relief if sufficiently imminent/substantial, but in a damages-only posture plaintiffs generally need either actual harm/materialization or a separate concrete harm caused by the exposure to the risk itself, and they must establish standing for damages specifically.
overextension_cautions: Do not let the memo collapse the injunctive-relief risk rule into a damages rule without the additional qualifiers.
Flag absolute wording like “always,” “categorically,” or “as long as the risk is substantial” if used to justify damages standing.
If the memo claims “risk of future harm is never enough for standing,” treat that as overbroad because the packet allows it for injunctive relief.
Ensure the memo keeps the ‘separate concrete harm from exposure’ concept as a condition, not an optional afterthought, when discussing damages.

user_query: Need a partner-ready memo on our best Article III standing arguments in an FCRA damages class case pending in the Northern District of California. Plaintiffs are leaning hard on the Ninth Circuit’s 2020 Ramirez v. TransUnion decision and Ninth Circuit Spokeo remand cases to argue “risk of harm” is enough even for class members whose OFAC alert was never sent to a creditor. Can we move to dismiss or narrow the damages class on standing grounds, and how should we address the plaintiffs’ reliance on Ninth Circuit authority? Facts below.
scenario_facts: Putative Rule 23(b)(3) class seeks only statutory and punitive damages under the FCRA; no injunctive relief is requested.
TransUnion-style facts: OFAC “potential match” alerts were placed in all class members’ internal files, but only 1,900 members’ reports were disseminated to third parties.
The remaining ~6,300 members’ credit reports were not furnished to any third party during the class period, though their internal files contained OFAC alerts.
All class members received two mailings (a credit-file disclosure without the OFAC alert and a separate OFAC letter), and plaintiffs claim this format violated the FCRA.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes citation integrity only if the cited blocks actually support the legal propositions the memo uses them for (e.g., standing rules for damages, dissemination requirement, and treatment of risk-of-future-harm). If the memo asserts that a decision was reversed, vacated, or otherwise displaced, it must be able to point to a block that states that status; the grader will not give credit for “everyone knows it was reversed.” A response fails if it invents citations, cites blocks that do not exist, or attributes holdings to a case that the cited text does not contain. It also fails if it cites only syllabus/headnote material for a core holding when the packet includes opinion text. Pinpoint citations must match the stated proposition closely enough that a junior attorney could verify it from the quoted or paraphrased language. Minor paraphrasing is fine, but the memo cannot add new limiting language or new exceptions not grounded in the cited blocks.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite the syllabus/headnote as the only support for a holding.
Do not claim the Ninth Circuit case is still controlling without citing a block showing its current status.
Do not quote a block about injunctive-relief risk standards to justify a damages-standing conclusion without supporting text.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is about choosing the controlling authority in a Ninth Circuit federal case after the Supreme Court decided TransUnion LLC v. Ramirez. The response fails on precedence if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s pre-Supreme Court standing approach (e.g., the Ninth Circuit’s view that “material risk of harm” can support classwide damages standing for members whose reports were not disseminated) as controlling, without acknowledging that the Supreme Court reversed the Ninth Circuit’s judgment and rejected standing for the undisclosed internal-file group. It is also a precedence failure if the memo relies on the Ninth Circuit’s 2020 Ramirez opinion (or other circuit authority like Eleventh Circuit cases) as binding and uses it to recommend denying a standing challenge, despite the packet’s Supreme Court reversal/remand language. To pass, the memo must (i) identify the Supreme Court’s TransUnion decision as the controlling authority for Article III standing in federal court on these facts, and (ii) explain that the Ninth Circuit’s 2020 Ramirez standing holding cannot control because the Supreme Court reversed the Ninth Circuit’s judgment. The memo must then apply the Supreme Court’s rule to conclude that class members whose OFAC alerts were not disseminated lack standing for retrospective damages based on mere internal retention/risk of future harm, and it must treat any contrary Ninth Circuit discussion as at most historical/persuasive background.
precedence_cautions: Do not treat a court of appeals opinion as controlling after the Supreme Court reverses the judgment.
Do not use the Ninth Circuit’s Ramirez 2020 standing analysis to argue all 8,185 members have damages standing post-TransUnion.
Do not rely on out-of-circuit authority (e.g., Eleventh Circuit) over on-point Supreme Court authority.
Do not conflate standing standards for injunctive relief with standing standards for retrospective damages when hierarchy requires following the Supreme Court’s distinction.

user_query: Draft a short, partner-ready memo section on Article III standing for our motion to dismiss/decertify in an FCRA putative class action pending in the Northern District of California. The complaint seeks statutory and punitive damages and alleges harm mostly from inaccurate OFAC “terrorist” alerts and allegedly confusing two-mailing disclosures. We need the best argument that most (or all) absent class members lack standing for damages, even if the named plaintiff was denied credit.
scenario_facts: The putative class has 7,000 members; only 900 had any credit report with an OFAC alert disseminated to a third-party creditor during the class period.
The remaining 6,100 class members allege only that an OFAC alert existed in their internal credit file and created a risk of future dissemination.
All class members received two separate mailings: a consumer disclosure without the OFAC alert, followed by an OFAC letter without an additional summary of rights.
Plaintiffs seek retrospective damages (not injunctive relief) on reasonable-procedures, disclosure, and summary-of-rights theories.

grading_contract.citation_integrity_trigger_note: A response passes citation integrity only if the propositions it asserts are actually supported by the cited blocks, and the citations correspond to real packet blocks. It is not enough to cite generally to a case name; the cited block must contain the relevant holding or reasoning (for example, the concrete-harm requirement and the treatment of non-disseminated internal files). The response fails if it invents a holding, procedural posture, or “still good law” status that is not stated in the cited text. The response also fails if it uses fabricated citation tokens, cites blocks that do not exist, or attributes language to the Court that appears only in a syllabus/headnote without support in the opinion text. If the response quotes or paraphrases a rule (e.g., about risk-of-future-harm and damages standing), the cited block must actually state that rule in substance. Finally, a response fails if it implies that a dissent, concurrence, or lower-court opinion is the majority holding when the packet shows otherwise.
citation_integrity_cautions: Do not cite a syllabus/headnote block as the sole support for a key holding.
Do not claim a case was overruled, vacated, or reversed unless the packet expressly says so.
If you assert a specific standing rule, cite the block that states it, not just background facts.
grading_contract.precedence_trigger_note: This item is testing whether the memo correctly identifies and applies the controlling authority on Article III standing for damages claims in federal court when credit-report inaccuracies were not disseminated. The response fails if it treats the Ninth Circuit’s pro-standing analysis in the 2020 Ramirez decision as binding or as the governing standard, without acknowledging that the Supreme Court later reversed the Ninth Circuit and announced the controlling concrete-harm requirement for the undisseminated class members. It is also a failure to rely on, or to elevate, dissenting views as if they supply the governing rule when the packet shows the Court’s majority holding to the contrary. To pass, the memo must (1) anchor the concrete-harm/standing-for-damages rule in the Supreme Court’s TransUnion opinion and apply it to the 6,100 members whose reports were not disseminated, and (2) explicitly recognize the hierarchy point that the Supreme Court reversed the Ninth Circuit’s contrary standing ruling, making the Ninth Circuit approach non-controlling on this issue. A memo that reaches the correct bottom line but uses the reversed Ninth Circuit rule as its legal standard is still a precedence failure.
precedence_cautions: Do not present a reversed court-of-appeals decision as the controlling rule in the same case.
Do not say “Ninth Circuit law controls” when the Supreme Court has decided the issue differently.
Do not rely on dissents (even Supreme Court dissents) as if they are holdings.
When two authorities conflict, explain why the higher-court, later-in-time rule governs in federal court.
